issues.description: Endpoint path name mismatch between the problem statement and the server implementation. The problem statement explicitly defines the person endpoints as POST /persons, GET /persons, PUT /persons/{personId}, DELETE /persons/{personId} (problem_statement.md). In the solution server (PersonResource) the endpoints are implemented under the path "people" (e.g. @GetMapping("people"), @PostMapping("people"), @PutMapping("people/{personId}"), @DeleteMapping("people/{personId}")). This cross-artifact naming difference ("persons" vs "people") is structural and will confuse students implementing the client or server and trying to follow the specification.
issues.suggested_fix: Unify the endpoint path names across specification, server, and client. Preferably change the server mappings in PersonResource to use "persons" (i.e. @GetMapping("persons"), @PostMapping("persons"), @PutMapping("persons/{personId}"), @DeleteMapping("persons/{personId}")) to match the problem statement — or, if "people" is preferred, update the problem statement and all client code to use "people". Keep the same path everywhere to avoid student confusion.

issues.description: Inconsistent endpoint paths inside the solution client implementation: the solution's PersonController uses both "people" and "persons" paths. Specifically, addPerson and updatePerson use "people" (webClient.uri("people") and webClient.uri("people/{id}")), while deletePerson and getAllPersons use "persons" (webClient.uri("persons/" + id) and .path("persons")). This internal inconsistency in the client will cause mismatches with the server and make the provided solution non-functional when integrated with the server mapping.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the client use the same path string consistently for all person-related requests. Update PersonController so all methods use the same base path (e.g. "persons" to match the problem statement) and ensure it matches the server's PersonResource mapping. Alternatively, change the server mapping to the path chosen by the client, but do not mix both within the client or between client and server.

issues.description: The problem statement describes the REST endpoints under the path /persons (POST /persons, GET /persons, PUT /persons/{personId}, DELETE /persons/{personId}), but the solution server implementation exposes the person endpoints under /people (e.g. @GetMapping("people"), @PostMapping("people")). This lexical difference (persons vs people) refers to the same conceptual resource (the Person entity) but uses different path identifiers across artifacts, which will prevent students from mapping the problem's required endpoints to the actual server implementation and cause failed requests if they follow the problem text.
issues.suggested_fix: Choose a single REST resource path name and use it consistently across the problem statement, server, and client. Either (A) update the problem statement endpoints to /people everywhere to match the solution server, or (B) rename the server mappings from /people to /persons and update any client calls accordingly. Prefer applying the fix to the solution code and client so all code, templates, and the problem statement use the same path (for example, /persons).

issues.description: Within the solution repository the client PersonController uses both /people and /persons in different methods (addPerson and updatePerson call URIs under "people", while deletePerson and getAllPersons call URIs under "persons"). This internally inconsistent naming for the same conceptual resource (Person endpoints) creates confusion and will cause the client to fail to call the correct server endpoints consistently.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the client use the exact same resource path as the server for all methods. Update PersonController so all URIs target the same path (e.g. change the deletePerson and getAllPersons URIs from /persons to /people if the server uses /people, or change all client URIs to /persons and update the server accordingly). Consistency across all client methods and the server will remove mapping ambiguity and ensure requests succeed.
